title: Angular impulse - 2 disks are struck by a bar

content.question: In the two collisions depicted in the figures, a bar is rotating about a pivot at one end, labeled Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, on top of a horizontal surface before striking a disk that is initially at rest. The two collisions use the same bar but different disks, where the two disks are the same mass and size but are made of different materials. After each collision, the disk moves to the right at a constant velocity. After Collision <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, the bar stops rotating. After Collision <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the bar is still rotating in the same direction, and the disk is moving more slowly than after Collision <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. There is negligible friction between the bar and the pivot, between the bar and the surface, and between each disk and the surface. Which of the following correctly compares the magnitudes <math alttext="J sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="J sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> of the angular impulse delivered to each disk during the respective collisions, and provides evidence that supports the claim?

choices.label: <math alttext="J sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is greater than <math alttext="J sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. The bar’s angular momentum changes by a greater amount in Collision <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.

<math alttext="J sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is greater than <math alttext="J sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. The kinetic energy of the bar-disk system is the same before and after Collision <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.

<math alttext="J sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="J sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> are equal. Both disks bounce off the bar without sticking.

<math alttext="J sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="J sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> are equal. There is no external torque exerted on either bar-disk system about the pivot.

content.answer: <math alttext="J sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is greater than <math alttext="J sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. The bar’s angular momentum changes by a greater amount in Collision <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.
